The Caesar cipher is one of the earliest known and simplest ciphers. Each letter in the plaintext is shifted a certain number of places down the alphabet.
For example, with a shift of 1, A would be replaced by B, B would become C, and so on. The method is named after Julius Caesar, who used it to communicate with his army.

Tip: Rotate the cipher wheel to get the mappings for a key

In the simple substitution cipher, the letters of the alphabet are shuffled such that no letter is mapped to itself. Plaintext characters are substituted for their respective letter in the cipher alphabet.\nThe cipher alphabet acts as the key for this cipher where each key is 26 letters long. The number of possible keys is large but it is still not a strong cipher. This cipher can still be cracked using frequency analysis, word guesses and knowledge of the underlying structure of the English language.

The Vigenère cipher consists of several Caesar ciphers in sequence with different shift values. In this cipher the keyword is repeated to the end of the plaintext. Each letter in the plaintext uses its corresponding keyword letter to determine the cipher text letter.
The example below uses the keyword SECRET to encrypt a message:
Plaintext: HELLO WORLD
Keyword: SECRE TSECR
Ciphertext: ZINCS PGVNU
Because the key repeats, this cipher can be cracked if an adversary guesses the keys length. The Kasiski test is one method used to break this cipher.

Tip: Use the cipher wheel to determine the mapping of each letter
